image.altText: Dennis Pashen in his surgery

props.synopsis: Long-time Tasmanian GP Dennis Pashen is being remembered as a fierce advocate for rural health and "just a fantastic fella" after his death in a swimming accident on Bruny Island on Thursday.

title.children: 'A fantastic fella': Tributes for long-time GP and rural health advocate after swimming death off Bruny Island

image.altText: A black and white class photo with a male teacher. The children's faces are blurred.

props.synopsis: A Victorian government inquiry has laid bare how the state's education department protected paedophile David MacGregor, allowing him to teach and coach children for almost three decades despite multiple warnings from children and their parents.

title.children: The horror story of paedophile teacher David MacGregor has finally been laid bare

image.altText: A man with his arm around a woman, both in uniform and both looking at the camear

props.synopsis: Oleksandra andÂ Oleksandr fight in the same Ukrainian combat unit, trying to push back invading Russian forces on the frontlines. Their bond runs even deeper than most.

title.children: The father-daughter fighting team helping to drive Russia out of Ukraine

image.altText: A graphically altered image of a newspaper front page, a parcel and a post office.

props.synopsis: A newborn baby was found dead in a parcel, with police on opposite sides of Australia bewildered by who could've sent it. Now, DNA advancements are offering hope the six-decade 'baby in the post' mystery could soon be solved.

title.children: Decades after the grisly discovery of a baby in the post, could DNA finally solve the case?

image.altText: A man in a suit holding a laptop walks past a group of photographers outside

props.synopsis: When a billionaire darling of Silicon Valley became the CEO of OpenAI and built ChatGPT, he was sure it would change the world. But in one week, the collaboration between the company's altruistic board and thriving business unravelled, leaving theÂ industry asking just how open AI is going to be in the future.

title.children: OpenAI's non-profit board took a stand. But this is Silicon Valley, and the billionaires won

image.altText: an image grab from a simulation of a driver in a car about to enter the rozelle interchange

props.synopsis: The Rozelle Interchange comprising ofÂ 16.6 kilometres of road tunnel welcomes its first lot of motorists, as drivers are warned to brace for weeks of traffic disruption and delays.

title.children: Australia's largest underground motorway maze opens in Sydney. How confusing is it to navigate?

image.altText: A photo of a person driving a car at sunset, taken from behind the driver's seat

props.synopsis: Psychologists say some Australians are cancelling their autism assessment appointments after learning they could be required to disclose their condition under Fitness to Drive standards.

title.children: Would you still pursue an autism diagnosis if it meant you might lose your driver's licence?

image.altText: A women with dark red hair faces the camera with a somber expression on her face.

props.synopsis: Asherman's syndrome is under-diagnosed, misunderstood, and can lead to infertility. A group of mothers are campaigning for changes to protect women from a common medical procedure that can lead to a diagnosis.

title.children: This medical procedure can lead to infertility. A grassroots group is fighting for greater awareness

image.altText: a woman smiling under the sun

props.synopsis: The Queensland government allowed its mine safety commissioner Kate du Preez to keep acting in her role after accepting a lucrative job offer from a coal giant that has multiple convictions over workplace deaths and injuries, ABC Investigations has found.

title.children: Why a mine safety commissioner's new corporate gig is raising eyebrows about lobbying rules

image.altText: A man and a woman hugging two girls tightly while sitting in a hospital room.

props.synopsis: A delay in the release of Israeli hostages by Hamas is resolved, a Qatari official says after intervention by mediator countries.

title.children: Hostage deal back on track after Hamas delay in releasing captives, Qatar says

image.altText: A yellow wrecking crane in front of a partially demolished single-storey home on a hill overlooking Hobart.

props.synopsis: Houses are starting to be demolished in a project aimed at widening a major road into Hobart and to fix years of traffic congestion, but not all are convinced the plan will be enough.Â

title.children: Hobart might be a small city but it still has traffic jams. Will this be the fix?

image.altText: A dozen men in military uniforms stand around the rim of a ship floating on water

props.synopsis: HMAS Toowoomba, who's divers sustained minor injuries from a Chinese sonar pulse, has now begun joint naval patrols in the South China SeaÂ where regional tensions with Beijing are growing.

title.children: Australian warship involved in a Chinese sonar incident begins joint naval drills with Philippines in South China Sea

image.altText: Image of fire on the deck of Antarctic supply ship Everest.

props.synopsis: A scathing report finds equipment failure, overworked crew â many who had never been in Antarctic conditions before â as well as other factors contributed to a 2021 fire on board a ship which was thousands of kilometres from help "in some of the harshest and least-forgiving oceans on the planet".

title.children: Fire at sea thousands of kilometres from home â narrow escape from maritime disaster detailed in ATSB report

image.altText: two men are sitting at a dining table inside, there's a folder and teapot on the table

props.synopsis: Tasmanian artist Nathan Maynard advertised in a national newspaper for someone to donate their corpse to his art project. It's led to an unlikely friendship with Victorian Tony and "strangely normal" conversations about "giving me his body".

title.children: A newspaper ad asked for someone to donate their dead body to art â meet the successful applicant

subjects.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art

image.altText: Min Woo Lee watches on after completing a shot in front of the gallery

props.synopsis: Min Woo Lee rolls with Adam Scott's best punches and lands some of his own to earn a three-shot lead ahead of the Australian PGA Championship's final round.

title.children: Min Woo Lee burns off Adam Scott to take control of Australian PGA Championship

image.altText: Fahad at Red Rooster

props.synopsis: You might think all students stand equal at the doorstep of Australiaâs universities. But when Fahad tried to become a doctor, he had to navigate a system that seemed to punish him.

title.children: The odds of becoming a doctor when you live west of the 'Red Rooster line'

image.altText: Young teacher Brittany Herrington standing in a colourful Year 5 classroom.

props.synopsis: "Unsustainable workloads" and children with increasingly complex needs are among the reasons why more and more teachers are considering quitting, according to a new union survey.

title.children: Young teacher racks up 20 hours a week in overtime and $17k on work expenses

image.altText: A man with an earring, beard, braids and a shaved side of the head looks at a woman with purple hair and earrings

props.synopsis: The Sydneysider couple had planned their dream wedding at a famous movie set, but everything changedÂ when their cruise ship failed to meet New Zealand's biohazard rules.

title.children: Couple's planned wedding ruined when P&O cruise had to be turned back from New Zealand

image.altText: Canola crops with mountain ranges behind

props.synopsis: John Snooke says the Pacific Seeds' "garrison" canola variety's underperformance has cost him more than $70,000, but the company will not pay compensation.

title.children: A fifth of a farmer's canola crop died â then the seed company asked him to sign an NDA

image.altText: A fish and chip menu board

props.synopsis: State and federal consumer affairs ministers vote to implement compulsory country of origin labelling of seafood in all hospitality venues.

title.children: Restaurants will soon be required to tell you where their seafood was caught, under new country of origin rules

image.altText: A horse and cart placed outside the Coats Patons factory in a historical black and white  image.

props.synopsis: Tasmania's textile industry thrived soon after this iconic wool mill opened its doors in 1923. As the building's centenary is celebrated, former workers reflect on their time at Patons & Baldwins.

title.children: Once the largest employer of women in Tasmania, the Mill is remembered by workers a century after it spun its first yarn

image.altText: a person standing outdoors on a wheat farme next to machinery with storm clouds brewing and their arms up high

props.synopsis: As Western Australia sweats through the hottest November on record, eastern states are rejoicing through an extended run of stormy days.

title.children: Heavy rains mean Black Summer repeat unlikely as WA swelters through hottest November

image.altText: A composite image of three photos, including an old lady, a lady and a girl, and two girls

props.synopsis: Thirteen women and children who were among more than 200 Israelis taken hostage in the October 7 Hamas attack are returned home. Here's what we know about them.Â

title.children: After seven weeks in captivity, these Israelis are free. Here's what we know about them

image.altText: Lions players celebrate a goal with disappointed Cats players in the background

props.synopsis: Brisbane will play North Melbourne or Adelaide in the AFLW grand final after a preliminary final win over Geelong, but a knee injury to Dakota Davidson sours celebrations.

title.children: Lions advance to fifth AFLW grand final, but win over Cats comes at a cost

image.altText: a group women holding two young children sitting at the airport, four of the women are arrivals from gaza

props.synopsis: Dozens of Palestinians arrive in Sydney after being granted visas by the Australian government, some of them with nothing left but their personal identification.

title.children: 'Everything is lost': After 40 days trapped in a church in Gaza, the Tarazi family is finally safe in Sydney

image.altText: An aerial image showing a large line of surfers standing on a beach.

props.synopsis: More than 600 surfers, including a recent shark bite survivor, have taken part in the event to honour Zac Young, killed by a shark 10 years ago at the age of 19.

title.children: Surfing community unofficially breaks world record for largest paddle-out, in memory of shark victim

image.altText: Veronica and her two young children are sitting in a playground

props.synopsis: When my daughter discovered a pink tea set abandoned at our local playground, it was the greatest treasure to have ever been unearthed. Was it hers for the taking? I wasn't so sure.Â

title.children: Found a discarded toy at the playground? Finders keepers, losers weepers, right?

image.altText: Kids in traditional attire and face paint sit with their feet in a swimming pool. Children splash around them.

props.synopsis: In a place where the temperatures can soar above 40 degrees Celsius, children and adults alike are cheering the long-awaited return of their community pool.

title.children: For five years, kids in this community were swimming in croc-inhabited creeks. Finally, that's changed
